title: Lib Dem conference 2014 - Clegg rules out coalition with Tories unless rich pay more in tax: Politics live blog | Politics | The Guardian
summary: laws says lib dems would scrap coalition talks if labour insisted on clegg 's resignation .
lib dems back public services reforms .
norman lamb says he does not see miliband as a credible prime minister .
cable says small firms could get business rates cut in autumn statement .
webb proposes reducing the £ 37bn spent on tax relief for the wealthy .
tim farron says tory welfare cuts are 'borderline immoral '

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: lib dem delegates have voted for a motion committing the party to ending the role of the competition and markets authority in health .
( see 5.14pm . )
they have also committed the party to repealing any parts of the health and social care act making the nhs vulnerable to privatisation through the proposed eu/us free trade deal ( ttip ) .
in the debate , the mp john pugh launched a stinging attack on the act .
there was one single idea running through it - it was to take the idea of running a health service as an internal market to its logical extreme .

the idea , originally by [ margaret thatcher ] carried further by [ tony blair and alan milburn ] taken to its logical end by [ andrew lansley ] , turning one half of the nhs into buyers called commissioners and the other half into sellers , producers , and letting the producers - we used to call them hospitals , clinics , paramedics , all kinds of medical practitioners - compete amongst themselves for business .
but oddly letting the money be fixed by government decision and all the services be free .

and it 's a crazy , mad hatter 's , alice in wonderland type of market that offers none of the advantage of real markets and all of the downside , such as waste as the two sides employ an army of bean counters either side to make sure each is not short-changed and argue about tariffs and coding and a huge bureaucracy called monitor is set up to police the pseudo market .
like leeches , cod liver oil or voodoo , the internal market is not a universal remedy and like leeches , cod liver oil or voodoo , there 's no good evidence to show it actually works .
vince cable , the business secretary , has hinted that the lib dems would not agree to an in/out referendum in coalition negotiations with the conservatives in the event of a hung parliament .
( see 4.23pm . )
norman lamb , the care minister , has said he does not see ed miliband as a credible prime minister and warned it would be dangerous to go into coalition with labour on a low share of the vote .
ed miliband is to come under pressure from the liberal democrats to give scotland complete control over income tax despite opposition to the move from ed balls and gordon brown .

as severin carrell reports , senior lib dems have indicated they could support labour 's proposals for the scottish parliament to control £ 1.7bn worth of housing benefit if the labour leader sanctions a cross-party deal on allowing holyrood the full freedom to set its own income tax rates , even if they compete with uk tax levels .
delegates are still debating a proposal for staff working with children to have a mandatory duty to report child abuse sus but this seems almost certain to get approved .
my lunchtime summary is here .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .

documents.title: lib dems back public services reforms
text: after a debate lasting more than two hours , delegates have voted in favour of a party policy paper on the public services .

its proposals include : applying freedom of information obligations to private firms providing public services encouraging public service providers to make themselves more accountable , and awarding them accredited public service '' status when they do using targets with extreme caution '' backing the creation of a royal college of teachers ensuring all children are taught be a qualified teacher ( a key labour policy ) making all state schools teach the national curriculum repealing the rule requiring all new schools to be academies or free schools ensuring parity of esteem between mental and physical health services ending the role of the competition and markets authority in health extending evening and weekend opening for gps allowing public bodies to bid for rail franchises delegates also backed an amendment committing the party to repealing any parts of the nhs health and social care act 2012 dealing with competition where they are shown to make nhs services vulnerable to increased privatisation through international agreements on free markets in goods and services . ''
this is a reference to the proposed eu/us free trade agreement ( the ttip ) .
but delegates voted against a motion extending free school transport to young people up to the age of 18 .
the vote was close , but delegates accepted the advice of two ministers , david laws , the education minister , and susan kramer , the transport minister , who said this would cost too much .
there were claims it could cost as much as £ 2bn .
iain dale , the political publisher and blogger , explains on his blog why he thinks the lib dems will only hold 28 seats at the general election .
vince cable , the business secretary , also took a swipe at john redwood .

referring to redwood 's comment at the tory conference about firms paying a high price if they campaign for britain to stay in the eu , cable said intimidation of this kind could become a serious problem '' in the event of an eu referendum taking place .
the intimidation issue is potentially a serious problem if we do get to a referendum .
i came up to scotland during the long campaign and there were a lot of businesses who said they did n't wish to be publicly quoted .
sometimes it was for perfectly good industrial reasons - they did n't want their labour force , they did n't want their management to be quarrelling .
they did n't want to alienate their customers , which is understandable .
but some of them were frightened that there would be some kind of retribution .
if we are getting - hopefully not - a european union referendum , the last thing we need is for companies to be intimidated and prevented from saying what they really think .
cable was also asked if there was any prospect of lib dems agreeing to an in/out referendum in coalition negotiations if next year 's general election is inconclusive .
he replied : our commitment to the eu is an absolute one we have made it clear that the kind of referendum the tories want is just not on offer as far as we are concerned .
as i suggested in this post last week , this is now becoming one of the most interesting questions in british politics .
unfortunately cable did not give a clear answer , although he 's implying no .
vince cable , the business secretary , told a fringe meeting that green taxes were undermining exports by imposing costs on manufacturers that their foreign competitors did not face .
government efforts to compensate them did not go far enough , he said .
we do have an issue which should concern us as lib dems because of our very strong environmental commitments .

many of our manufacturing companies and exporters - particularly in areas like steel and cement and others which consume lots of electricity - are struggling against international competition because of the cost of energy .
they will argue that because we are trying to be green we are imposing costs on them which their competitors do n't have .
now of course a lot of that is unfair , and we have now introduced compensation schemes to offset some of those costs , but it does n't go the whole hog by any means .
there 's an issue here about the extent to which we are willing to tolerate the export of pollution because of our own system of taxing and charging industries which have a high energy content .
i think we are getting a good compensation system , but it is expensive and it 's a constant battle with the treasury to make sure it 's topped up .

on the world at one david laws , the education minister , said that it would be foolish '' for the lib dems to spend a lot of time worrying about what they should do in a hung parliament because there would probably only be one credible option .
it 's very rare for there to be hung parliaments , and it 's even rarer for a party to be in a position to choose its coalition partner .

usually there is only one permutation which is available that would actually create a majority in parliament , so i think it would be really foolish for the liberal democrats to spend ages and ages fantasising now about who we would like to be in power with after the next general election , when we do n't know if there will be a hung parliament .
if the country votes lib dem and they do so in size , they 'll get a lib dem government .

but the fact is that if we do n't get a lib dem government then we will use the votes that we have and the mps we have in parliament to deliver as many of the policies that we put in our manifesto as possible .
i 've taken the quote from politicshome .

documents.title: norman lamb says he does not see miliband as a credible prime minister
text: norman lamb , the care minister , has said that he does not see ed miliband as a credible prime minister and that a coalition with labour could be a mistake if labour won more seats than the tories , but not more votes .
lamb was speaking at a fringe meeting and my colleague rowena mason was there .
she 's sent me this .
norman lamb said it would be difficult to sustain a partnership with labour if the conservatives came second in terms of seats , but won support from the highest number of voters .
the lib dems would be in a particularly difficult position if it won more seats than ukip but gained a lower share of the vote overall .
with just seven months to go before the election , liberal democrats have been careful to leave the door open for a coalition with labour or another alliance with the tories .
many within the lib dems would feel more comfortable in a coalition on the left .
however , lamb said it could be a huge risk to go into partnership with miliband and warned the party to be careful .

the senior lib dem , seen as a potential leadership candidate , told a fringe meeting : there is the possibility that you could have labour as the largest number of seats but the tories as the largest number of votes .
if there is any possibility of labour in that situation going into coalition with the lib dems - the parties coming second and fourth - you would have zero honeymoon .
you would be attacked from the word go and it would be very , very hard to sustain it . ''
the audience applauded as he said : it is a political point , but it is one this party has to take very seriously : i 'm afraid i do n't see ed miliband as a prime minister .

the idea of us being latched into a labour government with a low percentage of the vote led by ed miliband what 's gone on with france under hollande , i think it could be enormously damaging for our party to be in that sort of relationship .
it does n't mean it should n't happen if it 's the right thing to do for the country , but the political implications i think are enormous .

documents.title: danny alexander 's speech - summary
text: here are the key points from danny alexander 's speech .
alexander said the lib dems would only approve deficit reduction measures that hit the rich more than the poor .
he announced a new fiscal rule , reinforcing a point made by nick clegg in his interview this morning .
alexander said : having listened to the tory conference , today i want to propose a new , third fiscal rule that we will put in place .
a fairness rule .
twice a year the treasury has published an analysis that shows how much each income group is contributing to deficit reduction .
i insisted on it .
and every time it has shown the same thing - everyone has done their bit , but the best off have contributed the biggest share of their income to help pay down the deficit .
rightly so .
so our third fiscal rule will require that to be the case until the deficit is gone .

this new fiscal rule '' would follow two others adopted by the party , he said : that debt should be sustainable by the mid 2020s , and that the lib dems would run a balanced budget , but allow for investment in productive economic infrastructure .
he attacked the tories for suggesting at one point that further devolution to scotland would be conditional on parliament approving english votes for english law '' ( evel ) .
he seemed to be referring to david cameron and william hague .
alexander said : within hours of the result , some conservatives were trying to score cheap party advantage by making powers for scotland appear conditional on a particular change for england .
pathetic .
wrong .
desperate nonsense .

cameron and hague have subsequently withdrawn the suggestion they were making on the friday after the referendum , and said further devolution to scotland will go ahead regardless of what happens to evel .
alexander said a new crackdown on corporate tax avoidance would raise hundreds of millions of pounds .
for many years , a small minority [ of multinational companies ] have flitted between tax havens , paying little or nothing anywhere .
those days are coming to an end .
our government has led the way in a global movement to rewrite the tax code .
that work is nearing completion , and i can tell you britain will be one of the first countries to put the new rules into action .
this december , we will take the first steps with new rules to stop firms lending money across borders just to minimise tax .
anyone ever heard of hybrid mismatches ?
thought not .
well the good news is we 're stopping them .
this could yield hundreds of millions of pounds and it will put britain in the lead with the first of many steps to implement the new global tax rules .
liberal democrats , we will ensure everyone , however big , pays their fair share .
he said the lib dems wrote the recovery plan '' .
just like i wrote this speech - we wrote the recovery plan .
just look at its main elements .
cutting taxes for working people .
not a conservative idea - a liberal democrat idea .
a dramatic increase in apprenticeships .
not a conservative idea - a liberal democrat idea .
investment in infrastructure - including pushing for upgrades to the a1 and a303 .
not a conservative idea , a liberal democrat idea .
record investment in renewable energy .
not a conservative idea - a liberal democrat idea .
balancing the books , and doing so fairly .
you ever hear that from the tories ?
no !
absolutely core lib dem thinking .
this recovery would n't be happening without liberal democrats in government .
he claimed the two-party system contributed to the 2008 financial crash .
the crash of 2008 was the product of the old two party system .
for decades , labour always borrowed too much .
for decades , the tories cut too much .
like two drunks fighting over the steering wheel of the car , the lurches between one single party administration got bigger and bigger , until they crashed it completely .
( it 's a nice theory , but i 'm not sure it 's true .
the 2008 crash hit many eu countries which do n't have two-party politics . )
danny alexander delivering his conference speech lawson/pa
it would not be a danny alexander speech without a crackdown on tax avoidance .
today he 's just announced he 's going to stop hybrid mismatches '' .
apparently that 's going to save us hundreds of millions .
i 'll post a full summary of the speech shortly .
danny alexander , the chief secretary to the treasury , is addressing the conference now .
i 'll post a summary when he 's finished , but at the moment the main point of interest is his dress code .
chris ship ( @ chrisshipitv ) who advised @ twitterid to take a no-tie , no-jacket approach to his speech ?
# ldconf isabel hardman ( @ isabelhardman ) what the camera can not tell you is danny is tieless .
it 's the sort of sartorial choice that gets written up as `` on manoeuvres '' # ldconf paul waugh ( @ paulwaugh ) danny alexander making his big speech sans tie .
now that he 's sans spex too , is he lining up as a libdem leader-in-waiting ?
isabel hardman ( @ isabelhardman ) sorry i should also have mentioned that danny has also rolled up his sleeves for this speech

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: nick clegg has signalled that the lib dems would refused to join a second coalition with the conservatives unless they agreed to raise taxes on the rich to fund deficit reduction .
in an interview on the andrew marr show ( see 11.12am ) , clegg expressed astonishment that the chancellor , george osborne , planned to exempt the rich from any further tax rises .
he spoke as other senior lib dems used interviews and speeches to condemn the welfare cuts proposed by the conservatives at their conference last week .
tim farron , the outgoing party president , said they were borderline immoral '' .
steve webb , the pensions minister , has proposed reducing the £ 37bn spent on tax relief for the elderly .
( see 1.15pm . )
norman baker , the home office minister , has called for reform of the drugs law .

speaking in a debate on crime which saw delegates back a motion calling for those caught with drugs for personal use to be given treatment rather then punishment , and for a review into whether cannabis should be legalised , baker said drugs laws were based on the prejudices of yesterday '' .
he said : medicinal cannabis is a very sensible objective to take forward .
why should people who are ill not have access to medicine which helps them when other medicine does n't ?
and more to the point they are made criminals when they access the cannabis themselves .
i support any efforts to make this more logical and more compassionate .
let 's get some facts based compassionate rational evidence for the drugs policy rather the prejudices of yesterday which do n't work .
lib dem delegates have backed a call for journalists to be given greater protection from police attempts to access their phone record .
they supported an amendment to the crime motion on this subject tabled by evan harris , the former mp and assistant director of hacked off .
harris condemned the way the police were able to access the phone records of tom newton dunn , political editor of the sun .

liberal democrats , just like my organisation , believe that there 's much more that can be done to enhance press freedom , especially in the areas of public interest journalism and investigative journalism .
the first is ripa ( regulation of investigatory powers act ) and the lack of safeguards for journalistic material , including confidential sources and indeed legally privileged material .

operation alice into the plebgate affair farrago revealed - as it had to do as it was made to be published - that the police had got the phone records of the mobile phone and the desk phone of tom newton-dunn , the political editor of the sun .
now it 's unlikely they would have found many calls to and from liberal democrats , but that 's not the point .
there was no judicial oversight or indeed any oversight for the police of that decision .
the police authorised themselves to do that , something they can not do under ( the police and criminal evidence act ) and should not be allowed to do under ripa .
there must be greater safeguards .
jeremy browne , the lib dem former minister , has said that the lib dems should defend their record in government and not focus too much on attacking the conservatives .
speaking on the sunday politics , he said .
the greatest danger we have as a party is having one foot in government and one foot out of government , looking like we are primarily pitching our appeal that we have reined in the conservatives .

i think we have to be self-confident about being a governing party because if we end up half in and half out , people who like the government , they will vote for the parties unequivocally enthusiastic about being in government , the conservatives ; if they do n't like the government , they 'll vote for the parties that are unequivocally critical , i.e .
labour or ukip .
he also said that if the conservatives and the lib dems stood at the next election on a joint platform , they would win .
if the coalition was standing in the general election in may , in my view it would win comfortably .
the normal proposition is do you want more of the same , do you want to re-elect the government , or do you want to change ?
and i think in this country next may people would vote for this government to continue if it was an option on the ballot paper .
clegg has announced that the earnings threshold for the carers allowance is being lifted to £ 110 per week .

as the press association reports , this £ 8 increase means more carers can work part time and claim the full £ 61.35 a week allowance , which is a non-contributory benefit available to people who have given up the opportunity of full-time paid employment to provide substantial care , of at least 35 hours a week , to a severely disabled person .
alistair carmichael , the scottish secretary , has urged nicola sturgeon , who is set to replace alex salmond as scotland 's first minister , to rule out another independence referendum .
he told the conference : the threat of a second referendum would not only distort scottish politics but it would undermine the provision of business and jobs here too .

documents.title: cable says small firms could get business rates cut in autumn statement
text: vince cable has hinted the coalition will offer tax breaks to small companies struggling with the business rates at the autumn statement later this year , my colleague rowena mason reports .
she 's sent me this .

although tax announcements are generally the responsibility of chancellor george osborne , the lib dem business secretary appeared to make a claim on the policy before any announcement is made by the conservatives .
he made the comments at a fringe event at lib dem party conference , having long pushed for a review of the rates system .

asked whether small businesses could get more rebates , he said : on business rates , i had hoped at conference we would be able to announce something that would really help small businesses on business rates , because this is a real problem area .
we have n't quite got to the conclusion of these discussions , but i think there will be something positive in the pipeline at the autumn statement . ''
last year , george osborne will announce that rate rises would be capped at 2 % rather than going up in line with inflation and extended rate relief to small businesses .
the area of small business rates is a battleground election issue .

the conservatives have always cast themselves as the party of business but ed miliband has offered to scrap a planned inflation-linked rise in rates due in april 2015 and freeze them at the 2014 level the year after for small businesses , in a tax cut worth £ 800m .
vince cable visiting a bioscience centre in edinburgh on friday lawson/pa

documents.title: webb proposes reducing the £ 37bn spent on tax relief for the wealthy
text: lib dem ministers have been facing questions all morning about how they would cut the deficit .
andrew marr asked nick clegg about this .
and andrew neil went over the same ground more aggressively with david laws .

laws outlined various tax increased proposed by the lib dems ; when neil said there these only accounted for a small amount of the money that needed to be found , laws said that labour and the tories were even worse at saying how they would eliminate the deficit .
but there is an obvious answer .
and steve webb , the pensions minister , may have just revealed it in his speech .
he was not announcing policy , but he gave a clear hint where the lib dems ( or labour perhaps ) may try to raise billions in extra revenue .
here are the key points from the speech .
webb proposed reducing the £ 37bn spent on pension tax relief , which he said overwhelmingly benefited the rich .
yesterday the lib dems announced plans to save £ 500m by reducing the lifetime pension tax relief limit from £ 1.25m to £ 1m , but webb suggested the lib dems could go much further .
we also need to tackle the inequity - or should i say iniquity - of the current system of tax relief on pensions .
if i want to put £ 1 into my pension it only costs me 60p - the taxpayer contributes the other 40p through higher rate tax relief .
but if someone on an average wage wants to put £ 1 into their pension it costs then 80p - the taxpayer only contributes 20p .
that can not be right .
we spend something like £ 37 billion a year on tax relief for pensions and yet overwhelmingly the money goes to those who are already well off and who will end up with decent pensions in any case .
we could probably spend less on pension tax relief overall - helping to contribute to deficit reduction - but also rebalance the money so that everyone , rich or poor , got help at the same rate .
we need to work through the details , but in my view the next government will need to address this longstanding unfairness .
he floated the idea of getting workers to automatically increase their pension contributions when the get a pay rise .
having got millions of people in to workplace saving we need to get them saving more than the bare statutory minimum of 8 % .
i am quite attracted to the idea that when you start a job the norm is that each time you get a pay rise a part of the extra cash goes into your pension , building up gradually to a worthwhile sum .
you could opt out of this 'automatic escalation ' but unless you actively chose to opt out , you would gradually contribute more .
he floated the idea of having a single assessment process for disabled people .

we should be looking to see whether the needs of disabled people could be assessed in one go for their different disability benefits and social care needs , rather than having constant assessments and reassessments for different benefits and separately again by local authorities .
earlier the conference voted for a motion explicitly calling for this .
he defended universal credit .

although there will be teething problems '' , he said , in my view the sooner we can move people onto this new and more streamlined system , the better it will be for people who most depend on the benefits system . ''
he said the lib dems no longer had to say what the tories would have done without the lib dems in coalition because the tories were now making this obvious with their manifesto plans .
cab campaigning ( @ cabaction ) minister for pensions @ twitterid1 takes to the stage # libdem14
the lib dems have put out a press release about the welfare motion passed earlier .
they say the proposal to allow councils to play a greater role in the work programme is significant .
here 's an extract from the news release .
liberal democrats are looking to improve the work programme by giving a greater role to local authorities .
areas such as greater manchester are already taking on elements of back to work support , and are able to provide a more joined up package of support for those furthest from the workplace .

giving las a greater role will help to address the following : - for some groups - 18-24 years old , older claimants and those with health or mental health issues - the work programme has not performed well .
- success is not consistent across local areas , with less success in areas with historically weak labour markets .
- the large size of contracts awarded has made it difficult for small specialist voluntary sector organisations to win contracts .
steve webb , the pensions minister , is addressing the conference now .
he was introduced by chris maines , the chair , as the best pensions minister in the world .
webb did not comment on that , but he did say he was britain 's longest-serving pensions minister .
the speech is still going on .
i 'll post a summary when i 've seen the text .

documents.title: laws says lib dems would scrap coalition talks if labour insisted on clegg 's resignation
text: david laws , the lib dem education minister , told the bbc 's sunday politics that the lib dems would walk away from coalition talks with labour if labour tried to insist on the party getting rid of nick clegg las leader .
he did not talk about labour specifically , but i think it 's fair to assume that this would not be an issue in coalition talks with the conservatives .
laws said : we not having some other party tell us who are leader is .
nobody is going to dictate to the liberal democrats who leads our party - we will decide that ourselves thank you very much , and we have decided it .
laws also dismissed the sunday politics poll showing that only 36 % of lib dem candidates would be happy to put a of nick clegg on their leaflets .
( see 9.16am . )
the findings were based on the views of just 24 respondents , he said , a tiddly number '' .

documents.title: tim farron says tory welfare cuts are 'borderline immoral '
text: tim farron , the outgoing lib dem president , told sky news earlier that the welfare cuts proposed by the conservatives were borderline immoral '' .
and there were a couple of other good lines in the interview .
here 's a summary .
farron said the welfare cuts proposed by the tories were borderline immoral '' .
it 's very important that people know that a conservative-only government would be lacking in compassion .
they are indeed the nasty party that theresa may said they were .
they are trying to balance the books on the backs of the poor , something which is un-british and borderline immoral .
and the labour party , if they were allowed to govern on their own , would be the incompetent rabble they were that got us into this mess in the first place .
he claimed that the polls showed that there was everything to play for '' .

the polls show , if nothing else , that everything is to play for , and the other polling we 've seen , lord ashcroft polling , show the liberal democrats doing very strongly in the liberal democrat-tory marginals that we need to do well in .
and every reason for us to be very positive about what 's coming forward without being at all ignorant of the fact that it 's going to be a big challenge .
he said he was not thinking about whether to stand in the next leadership election .

asked if he would like to lead the party when nick clegg resigned , he replied : let 's be honest , anybody who thinks about things like this , at a time like this , anybody giving any head space to that is not loyal to the party , is putting themselves ahead of the common good , so i 'm giving that no thought .
i 've taken the quotes from politicshome .
lord ashdown , the former lib dem leader , told radio 5 live this morning that he hated '' the tories but that this would not stop the lib dems working with them again if necessary .
i do n't like the tories , i hate the tories , i 've fought the tories all my life .
i hate both of the other parties who have wrecked this country there should n't be some namby-pamby version of politics where we all go around saying how terribly nice everybody is .
that 's not the nature of the house of commons .
there 's a robustness about the political debate .
the fact that we use tough language about each other in the context of an election , what do you expect ?
but it does n't stop us working with them .
you 've seen evidence of that .
i 've taken the quote from politicshome .
lord ashdown speaking at a lib dem rally yesterday cheyne/reuters
the lib dems have backed a motion on welfare reforming calling for a review of universal credit .
it also calls for benefits sanctions to be used only as a last resort , for a single assessment process for disability benefits and for councils to play a greater role in running the work programme .
in the debate liz lynne , the lib dem former mp and mep , attacked the bedroom tax and said not enough mps had experience of living on benefits .

we should never have brought [ the bedroom tax ] through in the first place in that form , and now we have ridiculous situations , which we heard at the conservative party conference , that benefits are going be frozen if they get back in .
a few pounds a week might not mean much to them but if you 're trying to survive on very little it means a great deal .
it 's all very fine for some people but not enough mps have had the experience of trying to live on benefits .

i know when i was in the house of commons and i was a frontbench spokesperson on social security , i was the only mp working on benefits who had actually been on benefits myself and knew what it was like .
i 've noticed some hashtag confusion going on about twitter .
if you follow tweets with the hashtag # ldsconf , you 'll find references to a conference apparently attended by 100,000 people , celebrating one of the world 's great inspiration .
it 's not the lib dem conference , but the church of jesus christ of latter-day saints ' ( lds ) conference in salt lake city .
if you are interested in the # ldconf , leave out the s. i suppose our american friends who are having to read about nick clegg deserve an apology .
cllr ben stevens ( @ stevenswidcombe ) this .
this is the @ twitterid clegg that people need to see .
passionate , clear , and absolutely right .
# ldsconf

documents.title: nick clegg 's interview with andrew marr - full summary
text: this was one of those interviews where the most candid insight came from one of the questions , not one of the answers .
after all you 're saying , it is hard to see how you and david cameron could put together a new legislative programme , andrew marr said .
quite .
here are the key points from the interview .
it 's a fuller version of the summary that i posted earlier .
and , having listened to the quote again , i have firmed up the line about the lib dems wanting the rich to pay more .
clegg is effectively making this a red line '' issue in any potential coalition negotiations with the tories .
clegg said that lib dems would not form a coalition with the conservatives unless they accepted that the wealthy would have to pay more tax as a contribution to cutting the deficit .
the lib dems were proposing such taxes , he said .
as examples , he cited the mansion and tax and the taxes proposed by danny alexander yesterday .
of course the lib dems are not going to enter into government with an economic agenda which would only penalise the working-age poor .
it is anathema to everything we believe in .
he said the conservatives had abandoned the progressive values they claimed to support in 2010 .
four years ago they said they were committed to the environment , civil rights and compassionate conservatism , and that they were not obsessed by europe .
on all four points , they have reversed their stance , he said .
when i first went into coalition with david cameron in may 2010 , he said , the conservatives said they cared about the environment .
they self-evidently do n't .
that they are not going to bang on about europe ; they only bang on about europe .
that they are going to protect civil liberties and human rights .
they now want to trash them .
and , most important , they said they were compassionate conservatives , but george osborne confirmed last week that they are now burying compassionate conservatism .
he also said that labour and the conservatives were offering the public a dismal choice '' .
what they are presenting to the british people is a dismal choice between a broken economy at the hands of labour and a divided society at the hands of the conservatives .
he rejected suggestions that the polls showed the lib dems would lose many seats at the election .
national polls were not a good guide to what would happen in particular seats , he said .
i think , to be blunt , these national poll ratings do n't tell you very much any more because the country has become so varied .
he said he did not favour reducing the welfare cap from £ 26,000 to £ 23,000 , as the tories propose , but he did not rule out the proposal either .
he dismissed the theresa may adviser who called him a wanker '' as silly '' and juvenile '' .
rudeness from silly , juvenile conservative special advisers does not bother me at all .
he said the lib dems would never accept leaving the european convention on human rights .
he said he would be happy for nigel farage to be included in the televised leaders 's debates .
he rejected a suggestion from lord richards , the former head of the armed forces , that the size of the army needed to be increased in the light of the threat posed by islamic state ( isis ) .
clegg said : we need to take it extremely seriously .
i think it is a challenge and a threat , a very serious threat to our way of life that will last for a very long period of time .
how you respond to it , i think , is not quite as straightforward as david richards - much as i respect him - suggests .
i do n't think it 's a question of just ramping up conventional armed forces again as if we were fighting state-to-state conflicts .
nick clegg being interviewed by andrew marr j mitchell/getty images
q : what 's your view on english votes for english laws '' ?
clegg says we need a wider constitutional convention .
on house of commons votes , it has to be fair votes for english voters .
the tories only won 38/39 % of the votes in england .
there should be a proportionate system .
q : should nigel farage be included in tv debates ?
clegg says that he is relaxed about that .
but he thinks the debates should go ahead .
he wishes the other parties would agree to that now .
and that 's it .
i 'll post a summary shortly .
q : how could you and david cameron put together a new legislative programme ?
clegg says that the lib dems stand for the reasonable , decent centre .
he does not accept that the country has to choose either the conservatives or labour .
q : would the lib dems have anything to do with leaving the european convention on human rights ?
no , says clegg .
trashing '' human rights to go after ukip votes is not the way to go , he says .
q : what do you feel about theresa may 's special adviser calling you a wanker ?
( marr does not use the word , but that 's what he means . )
clegg says he is not bothered about silly , juvenile '' comments from an adviser .
but the issues at stake , the snooper 's charter and the claim the lib dems have blocked measures that would protect children , are very important .
q : why stay in government with the tories if they are so bad ?
clegg says the lib dem are restraining the tories .
they have anchored them in the centre ground .
in 2010 the tories said they cared about the environment ; they do n't .
they said they would not bang on about europe ; now they do .
they said they cared about civil rights ; now they do n't .
and they said they were compassionate conservatives ; now , self-evidently , they are not .
q : would you stop them cutting the welfare cap from £ 26,000 to £ 23,000 ?
clegg says he does not believe the case has been made .
he would look at this , but it is not lib dem policy ?
q : would you stop the tories doing that if you were in coalition with them again ?
clegg says right now he is not persuaded that is the right thing to do .
what was most interesting was that the tories did not propose tax cuts for the rich .
q : so is that a red line ?
clegg says the lib dems would not accept a programme that only penalised the working age poor .
q : so they are fine as long as you bash the rich as well ?
clegg says how you distribute the burden is crucial .
the lib dems say rich pensioners should lose their free tv licences .
it does not raise a huge amount of money , but it is a symbolic move .
q : the polls show you will lose a lot of seats at the election .
clegg says he does not accept that .
the national polls do not tell you much now , because of the way the electoral battle is fragmented , he says .
he says labour and the tories are presenting the british people with a dismal choice '' : a broken economy , or a broken society .
the lib dems would offer a strong economy and a fair society .
where that message gets out , it has resonance .
q : how would you cut the defict ?
by raising taxes ?
yes , says clegg .
q : beyond the mansion tax ?
clegg says danny alexander set out ideas yesterday , for raising money from the wealthy through changes to taxes on pensions and on dividends , and from abolishing the shares for rights '' scheme .
q : the mansion tax goes to the nhs .
no , says clegg .
it would raise £ 1.5bn and would go on deficit reduction .
q : but these proposals are modest .
you will have to raise more .
clegg says the received wisdom is that you should cut the deficit with 20 % tax rises , and 80 % spending cuts .
but the tories are not raising taxes , he says .
they would cut spending in a way that would hit the working poor .
the british people want balance .
that 's what the lib dems are offering .

documents.title: nick clegg 's interview on the andrew marr show
text: andrew marr is interviewing nick clegg now .
clegg starts by saying the threat from islamic state is one that will last for a long time .
but dealing with it is not just a matter of ramping up the armed forces , he says .
the commons vote could be a harbinger of things to come .
in the future , states will have to come together to form alliances to deal with threats like this .
q : should there be another commons vote , to allow air strikes against islamic state ( isis ) in syria ?
no , says clegg .
in iraq the situation is reasonably clear .
in syria it is more complex .
the americans are making a big effort to build up the syrian opposition .
that is the way forward .
q : would you oppose a vote for air strikes in syria ?
clegg says that is not what he favours now .
the combination of ground forces and air strikes needs to be thought through .
q : so you would not support air strikes in syria ?
clegg says if the government favoured it now , it would have done it .
but it does not think the case is straigthforward now .
nick clegg spoke at a rally at the conference last night .
he attacked both main parties , but he was particularly critical of the tories .
imagine britain after five years of a majority conservative government , he said .

britain , diminished and divided after a botched attempt to renegotiate our relationship with europe and a vote to withdraw from europe ; companies pulling out of the uk left right and centre ; the markets losing confidence , hiking up our borrowing costs and halting the recovery in its tracks .
workers fearing for their jobs , not just because the companies they work for are plunged into uncertainty but because their bosses can fire them at will , no questions asked .
the young and the working poor hit time and time again as george osborne takes his axe to the welfare budget with no regard for the impact on people 's lives .
the first aid in schools motion ( see 9.09am ) has been passed .

lib dem conference ( @ libdemconf ) first aid in schools results : motion passed # ldconf the conference is now debating welfare , but i will be focusing on the nick clegg interview , which should be coming up soon .
for the record , here are today 's yougov gb polling figures .

conservatives : 36 % ( up 1 point from yougov on friday ) labour : 34 % ( no change ) ukip : 13 % ( down 1 ) lib dems : 7 % ( up 1 ) conservative lead : 2 points ( up 1 ) government approval : -18 ( up 1 ) according to electoral calculus , this would leave labour the largest party , but 13 seats short of a majority .
sky 's faisal islam has been looking at the figures , and trying to establish why the labour lead has collapsed so dramatically since david cameron 's conference speech .

faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) but i 'm far more intrigued re : how yougov went from +7 labour ( 38-31 ) to +1 conservatives , in a day , the day of cameron tax cut speech : 1/2 faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) and the answer we can now see because the poll data has been released lies with an extraordinary change in voting intentions of ex libdems faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) yougov poll shows that , in one day of pms speech , 2010 ex libdem voters wanting to vote conservative > doubled faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) `` lost libdems '' broke 37 labour to 10 conservative when polled before cam speech , and then 29 lab :23 con after it faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) or out of 2000+ polled , over day of cam speech : 50 more votes for cons , 12 less for labour all ex 2010 libd voters

documents.title: lib dems candidates favour coalition with labour over tories by 3 to 1
text: lib dem candidates would prefer a coalition with labour after the election to a coalition with the conservatives by three to one , according to a poll for sunday politics .
the other findings are interesting too .
robbie gibb , the daily and sunday politics editor , has been tweeting them .
robbie gibb ( @ robbiegibb ) excl : 27 % of lib dem candidates think nick clegg is an electoral asset .

45 % disagree # bbcsp/comres ( 1/5 ) robbie gibb ( @ robbiegibb ) excl : just 36 % of lib dem candidates are happy to use photos of nick clegg in their campaign literature # bbcsp/comres ( 2/5 ) robbie gibb ( @ robbiegibb ) excl : 44 % of lib dem candidates would prefer a coalition with labour .

14 % would prefer the conservatives if hung parliament # bbcsp ( 3/5 ) robbie gibb ( @ robbiegibb ) excl : 61 % of lib dem candidates do not think the conservatives have been a good coalition partner # bbcsp/comres ( 4/5 ) robbie gibb ( @ robbiegibb ) excl : 41 % of lib dem candidates support tim farron as the next leader of the liberal democrats # bbcsp/comres ( 5/5 )
the conference proceedings have started .
it 's 9am on a sunday , and they 're debating a motion saying first aid skills should be included in pshe education at schools .
it 's very lib dem .
morgangd ( @ liberalmorgan ) `` by passing this motion , we can help create a life-saving generation '' # ldconf

nick clegg has written an article in the sunday mirror saying that , once the basic rate income tax threshold rises to £ 12,500 , the lib dems ' next priority would be to increase the employee national insurance threshold .
he also claimed that the conservatives ' decision to commit themselves to raising the basic rate threshold to £ 12,500 was an astonishing change of tack '' .
david cameron said last week that the conservatives now want to raise the tax-free allowance to the same level .
that 's an astonishing change of tack from a party which opposed it at the last election and has privately resisted it at every budget since .
when i said in the leaders ' debates in 2010 that i wanted to raise the tax-free threshold , david cameron turned to me and said : that 's a lovely idea , nick , but we ca n't afford it . ''
instead they wanted to cut inheritance tax for millionaires .
every year , in exchange for liberal democrat tax cuts , the tories have insisted on a trade-off .
they wanted to cut taxes for top earners .
they insisted on a scheme where employees give up their rights in exchange for shares .
they demanded a tax-break that would apply to a fraction of married couples at the expense of widows , widowers and people who choose not to marry .
even now , the other side of their announcement was a tax cut worth nearly five times as much for the top 10 % .
so much for fairness .
all three main uk parties have had the start of their annual conference overshadowed by a bigger story .
for labour , it was the scottish independence referendum , and david cameron english votes for english laws '' challenge .
for the tories , it was the defection of mark reckless .
and , when the lib dems started their conference in glasgow yesterday , the national news was dominated by the murder of alan henning .
i missed the opening of the conference .
but there 's a good summary of yesterday 's events in this post on stephen tall 's blog .
as for today , here 's the agenda .
9am : conference opens with a debate on first aid in schools .
9.25am : delegates debate a motion on welfare , calling for a review of the implementation of universal credit .
9.30am : nick clegg is interviewed on the andrew marr show .
10.20am : session on scotland , with speeches from alistair carmichael , the scottish secretary , and willie rennie , the lib dem leader in scotland .
10.50am : delegates debate a policy paper on crime , including proposals to relax drug laws and abolish police and crime commissioners .
12.30pm : steve webb , the pensions minister , speaks .
2.10pm : danny alexander , the chief secretary to the treasury , speaks .
2.40pm : delegates debate a policy paper on the public services .
5.10pm : delagates debate a motion on child abuse , include a proposal for making reporting child abuse sus a statutory duty for professionals .
as usual , i 'll be covering all the conference proceedings , as well as bringing you the best comment and analysis from the web .
if you want to follow me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid sparrow .

bulletin.text: Rolling coverage of all the developments at the Liberal Democrat conference in Glasgow, including Nick Clegg's interview on the Andrew Marr show.
